title: how keep TB address book in sync with Android "contacts" (on contacts.google.com, NOT gmail)?
content:
How can I keep a TB address book and my Android smartphone contacts (the ones on contacts.google.com, NOT Gmail ones) in sync, so any addition to one will show up on the other too?

(My email clients are of course TB on my Windows 10 desktop, and a downloaded app [NOT the standard Google one] on my Android smartphone. My email server is an ISP's IMAP server [NOT a Google server:-]. On my Android phone I use the regular Google "contacts" program, which correctly synchronizes to https://contacts.google.com. And I'm using the 64-bit version of TB 102.13.0.)

The vast majority of the recipes I can find do not work at all, probably either because they assume Gmail is somehow involved (it's NOT), or because https://contacts.google.com does not offer the expected services (as Gmail does), or because they do their job once and quit, rather than keeping the two lists in sync in perpetuity.

The recipe that seemed to do the best didn't involve either TB or Android at all, but rather involved going to Windows 10 Setup->Accounts->Email and Accounts->Add an account->Google. Unfortunately every time I clicked on the big 'G', it would appear to be doing something for a while (10 seconds?), but then simply quit with no error message and no changes to the list of accounts (i.e. the desired new Google account was _not_ created.)
creator: chuck68

title: Thunderbird font size and 2 screens with VERY different resolution >> Problem
content:
Hello from France. This is my first message, because I can't find a solution to a weird interface size problem with Thunderbird.

But let's begin :

I had a laptop with a 1600x900 screen resolution. On this laptop the screen scale in windows screen parameters was set to 100%. I also have a second screen connected via HDMI to the laptop with a 1920x1200 resolution. No problem with this configuration and thunderbird, regardles on wich of both screens thunderbird was running.

I juste replaced my laptop, and the new one has a screen with 3840x2160 resolution. On this one the screen scale in windows screen parameters is set to 250% so 99% of my apps (including firefox) show up with a correct font size. I installed thunderbird on the new laptop, and transfered my appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder from the old to the new laptop. All mail folders are here and sending or receiving mail work just fine as before. But on the new laptop's screen thunderbird appeared with very small fonts (not only the mail, the whole interface was "shrinked", as if thunderbird don't understand it has to rezise by 250% like said in windows parameters). After googling a little I found the "layout.css.devPixels.PerPX" parameter and modified the value from 1.2 to 2.6 So now on the laptop's screen with 3840x2160 pixels the size of the thunderbird interface is just OK. But when I open thunderbird on the second screen with 1920x1200 pixels the interface size is juste way too huge !

In comparison, with firefox, the interface adapts to each screen automatically, and the font size is OK on both screens.

I don't know what to do to have the same behaviour than with firefox, if somebody has an idea, I will be thankfull !

Best regards, Roland
creator: rolmat

title: TB no longer launches Brave browser with command line arguments
content:
Environment: Windows 10 with TB 102.12.0 and Brave browser (same would apply to Chrome)

I use the Brave browser with a series of command line arguments, primarily to set the user-data-dir to another disk and folder. This worked fine up through TB 68 by modifying network.protocol-handler.app.http (and .https) to specify the complete command line as "C:\Program Files (x86)\BraveSoftware\Brave-Browser\Application\brave.exe" --user-data-dir="E:\My Documents\Brave\User Data" --disk-cache-size=104857600 -–process-per-site -- "%1".

This broke in TB 91 and 102 with the handler selections moved to handlers.json. From what I've read so far, it's not possible to modify the "path" variable to work with additional arguments.

I've also edited the registry settings for "BraveHTML\shell\open\command" to include the same arguments.

Via the TB UI, http and https point to Brave (I've tried "default" and explicit). Running MS Process Monitor, I can see TB open that registry key and then ignore it and just launch brave.exe with no arguments.

I also tried setting the target to a .bat file which has the desired command line. Process Monitor shows TB opens that file. Brave is launched but does not honor the command line arguments. MS Process Explorer shows what looks like the fully correct command line including the URL passed from TB.

Is there a way to get this to work again? I've considered the mklink option but am nervous that it might actually overwrite the real profile location.
creator: newsletters1

title: security.tls.version.min - is this for SSL ot TLS?
content: Hi, I have been using Thunderbird to set up an SMTP email account. I have it working now, but one of the steps I took to get it to work was to edit the Thunderbird configuration. I changed security.tls.version.min from 3 to 1. I have changed it back to 3 now and my email account is continuing to work. TO me this suggests that security.tls.version.min is setting another variable somewhere that is not listed in the config. I am also confused why TLS would have a min version value of 3 by default. The latest version of TLS is 1.3 (at time of writing this). Is the tls.version.min also being used for SSL - which does in fact have a version 3.0? I just thought I should bring this to your attention because there seems to be a lot of talk in other forums about changing the tls.version.min to 1 to fix issues, and that doesn't work for all other issues and reducing the min version can create new issues - especially if my suspicion is correct, that it is also being used for SSL - ie security certificates. If this is the case, as a feature update, should SSL and TLS be given their own version config parameters in Thunderbird? Cheers, Ben
creator: ben155
